title: The roof, the roof, the roof is too low
body: The ceiling in the projection booth is too low. Simple as that. Currently, the floor of the projection booth is 2 feet off the ground, and the ceiling is 8 feet above the projection floor... making it roughly 10 feet off the actual floor. Here's the problem: the lens of the projector is centered 4 feet from the base. Meaning the center of the lens will be 6 feet off the actual floor of the auditorium (2 feet to projection booth floor + 4 feet to projector lens). That's not good. At that height (6 feet), anyone as tall, or taller than me will be able to completely block out the projector by standing up in the center of the back row. As you move closer to the screen, the obstruction will become less and less, but the height needed to block the screen will become smaller. That probably doesn't make much sense, so here's a quick diagram: As you can see, the closer you get to the screen, the less height it takes to obstruct the picture. The screen is only 5 foot 3 inches off the floor, which means that anyone taller than 5'6" would be able to block a small portion of the screen if they stood up in the first two rows. The obvious solution is to raise the projector, but to do that we'll have to cut a hole in the booth ceiling. Problem solved, right? Wrong. We have to leave room for an exhaust fan... but we don't know the dimensions of the fan yet. All we know is that it will weigh roughly 50 pounds and that it needs to be located above the projector. Chris (GC) is working on getting the exact specs for me, but I haven't heard back from him yet. Hold on... I'll call him real quick... *calling* He wasn't there. I left a voicemail. The higher we get the projector, the better off we'll be, BUT we also have to consider how tall we're making the projector itself. If we build a 2 foot platform for the projector to sit on, that means both the projector and the top reel are going to be taller than me, which isn't a good thing when it comes time to thread the film. GAHH! Can't we have anything go our way? Just once... I mean, COME ON! On a happier note, Andrew and Ellen (the building owners) just welcomed a new miniature version of themselves into the world. Congratulations! Also, on another side note, we're debating on whether we're going to represent the Moxie for First Friday on June 3rd. I think we need to do SOMETHING just to prove to everyone that the project isn't dead... but what? Any and all suggestions would be appreciated.
author: Dan

comments.author: Caleb
comments.body:
I say you put up a sign offering free tours of the building. 

And offering some cockroach dip would be a nice idea too. Actually you should try out the ole popcorn popper and offer free popcorn to people who wander in to visit you. Wouldn't that be a swell idea?

comments.body: Popcorn popper is a good idea... I doubt you can let the general public into a construction site, but you could rope off the door and allow people to look in... like at Anne Frank's house.

comments.author: Sam Spade
comments.body: Artwork. Now's the time to put up some local artwork. And popcorn. Not on the walls, but for people to cram in their pieholes.

comments.author: Evan Erwin
comments.body:
Popcorn is perfect because it's cheap and it reminds everyone what you're going to be, a movie theater. Server it by the piehole-full. Wow that made even less sense than I anticipated.

I'd also suggest chips and salsa, to remind them what you're -not- going to be: An authentic Mexican restaurant. Unless you changed your mind on that one.

Oh, and as for the troubles? They simply fill the space in your soon-to-be-published post-opening book: "Moxie and Me: How One Movie Theater Nearly Killed My Ass." Afterwards it is to be adapted into a film that will be so commercially hyped you'll never actually get to show it in its namesake (Dan will be played by Steve Buscemi, natch), but you will sell the DVD 3 months after it's release.

And by then there better be chips and salsa available in the lobby, or there'll be hell to pay.
